This is a quick release T-mount base for Ikelite handle. It only needs a metal t-mount base and some screws to attach it to the printed part.

The part needs to be cut in half in Slic3r to be printed in such a way that the filament layers are parallel to the tubular section of the part. Otherwise the rigidity will be lower and the part may break. Print with 100% infill. PLA works fine. The two parts can be glued together and secured with small screws, nylstop nuts and threadlocker.

description.text: Fit two extruders on one car - this is very much a first draft and doesn't include any provision for vertical adjustment.

For precision slicing and scoring, single-edge razor blades work better than utility knives and are cheaper than hobby knife blades. This handy folding blade holder makes using the blades easier and safer. It has an integral clip for locking the blade in securely, and it also has two storage slots in the handle for fresh blades. CAUTION: Be very careful when handling and using razor blades. Watch the demo video: https://youtu.be/3-_Lgt6VY1M

Printed in PLA with 0.2mm layers and 0.4mm line width. Both parts print without supports. Print them maybe a bit hotter than usual for good adhesion. The parts have a lot of fine detail, so also print more slowly than usual. Printing with a raft will ensure that the openings for the storage slots are sized correctly. Once printed, snap the blade holder pivot into the handle. The end of the blade holder has s little flexible clip - pull this up to slide the blade into place and make sure it clicks back into place after the blade is fully seated. Pull the clip up again to release the blade. CAUTION:
  • Be very careful when handling the razor blades. Do not try forcing the blade into or out of the holder
  • Only use light force when cutting with razor blades, otherwise you might break the blade or the holder.

comments.text: Do you use 0% infill for razor compartments?

comments.text: The razor storage compartments are already hollow and are unaffected by the % infill.

title: Forbidden Bridge Monkey Pawn
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Every good temple needs some monkeys, right?  So I mocked up a monkey pawn to use in the board game Forbidden Bridge.  Now you can play as a monkey instead of an adventurer, or perhaps use the monkey as a minion of the temple to scoop up any gems that fall into the jungle.  
I just thought it looked cool to have a monkey holding aloft the gems that they've stolen from the adventurers.   :)

The tail just doesn't want to print correctly on my Replicator 2.  The last bit past the hand comes out blobby.  But you know what?  It looks just fine, and a bit more natural that way.  So I stopped fiddling with it.  
No need for supports on this model, there's one built into the stl file to support the chin.  Just snap it off when the print is done.

Based on my favorite old tripod, this mechanism seems to work better than various things people have tried since.  
STL files are included for the basic configuration shown here. Some alternate cover plate designs are included in the 123d design file, as well as an example of a 45-degree mounting bracket.

To assemble, you will need:
  • Wood screws (#4, 3/8" to 1/2" in length, or similar) x 4
  • A compression spring between 6mm and 8mm in diameter
  • A 1/4-20 hex-head screw between 1/4" and 1/2" long.
    • You may need to vary the cover thickness to accommodate the length of 1/4-20 screw you have chosen. 3/8" Works best with the basic cover plate.

Box: moved mountholes a tad. Strenghtened the "standoffs".
Lids: Resized and moved around the text to make it print properly. 16-09: changed layout on the 5V and 7v top/lid - clearly marked +/- in and out and made an opening for the trimpot.
Removed the two side-slits in the casing.
Clamping devices on the lid has been fixed, and works much better now. New photo/s needs to be taken.

BOM:
Room for 2x M3 8mm screws. Shorter will do. I printed in 100% ABS with 0,2mm layer height. Guess you can print it how you like. No support is needed.
Remember to flip over the lids before printing (top down)

This thing was created in Solid Works

http://www.MiniPlan.co (New site launched, special offer trending) Update NOTE!! I've made MiniPlan V5.1 and now MIniPlan has its own Facebook page: V5.1 on Thingivers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1230335
MiniPlan - Robot Fun: https://www.facebook.com/miniPlanrobot/

The MiniPlan v5.0 is more smaller and more cheap !
https://www.facebook.com/miniPlanrobot/ Control Board : TOROBOT USC-20 & Bluetooth UATR to TTL
http://tw.taobao.com/item/45065229005.htm
http://tw.taobao.com/item/10194716671.htm Servo : Emax ES08DE or Emax ES08MD x 16 PCS ( +1 for Head )
http://www.amazon.com/Emax-ES08DE-Digital-Helicopters-Airplanes/dp/B00C85NPF2 Power Board : LM2596 DC-DC Buck Converter Step Down Module
Battery : DUALSKY 7.4V , 400mAh
Screws : M2 x 5mm , M2 x 8mm , M3 x 6mm
Bearing : 4x7x2.5 MR74ZZ This had always been a dream since I was little,
it's the 3D printers that allowed my dream to come true。
There are 16 servo motors that operated MiniPlan and performing different actions.
I used Rhinoceros to draw the mechanical parts and Arduino IDE to code the firmware.
I'm using Prusa i3 along with PLA.
The whole set took about 18~24 hours to complete.
The axles for the servo motor are not 3D printed because our 3D printer does not have the precision to print this. I'm from Taiwan, and my English isn't great.
But I try my best answer your question.
Thank you ~ ^_^

Assembly Instruction :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYPJHKjJyGM http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1040994 Use PLA ( total need about 300g )
MiniPlan5_40 Fill Density 30% & use Support
MiniPlan5_50 & 51 Fill Density 50%
Other Parts Fill Density 50% ~ 100% Head Parts List :

author: cuban_mamii

description.text:
Are you sick of people drinking out of your bottle?
Or are you even literally sick because of people drinking out of your bottle?
  • Print a Bottle Monster and it will protect the liquid of your choice simply by plugging it on top of the bottle!
    • [Update: Added BottleAdapter.STL this serves directly as the bottle cap and is a remix with this water tight cap: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806488] Choose from 3 different breathtaking scary monsters:
  • Aaaaaahh
  • Biiiiiiih
    and
  • Ciiiiiiih
    • They work also nicely as a decoration without the bottle adapter. The adapter can be put on and off the cap and head. Further applications of the monsters without the adapter includes:
  • Putting it on top of your yogurt so nobody eats it.
  • Putting it on top of your monitor so nobody looks at it.
  • Putting it in front of your window so nobody breaks in.
  • Putting it in your car so nobody steals it.
  • Putting it on top of your head so nobody looks at you wrong.

You need:
  • 1 of the 3 heads (A,B or C)
  • 2 eyes belonging to the head
    For the bottle connection:
  • 1 BottleAdapter.STL (Screws on normal sized bottles)
    Or - 1 BottleCapAdapter.STL (Connects to normal sized bottle caps)
  • 3 BottleCapAdapter-ConnectorPiece.STL (Connects to the head)
    • The eyes need to be pushed in with some force. (let the pupils point away from you while doing so.) MonsterA-Head-MouthClosed.STL and MonsterB-Head.STL require no glue. MonsterA-Head-TeethSeperate.STL requires to glue in:
  • 2x MonsterA-TeethLower.STL and 2x MonsterA-TeethUpper.STL
    the longer sides of teeth need to point inwards.
    • MonsterC-Head.STL requires to glue in:
  • 2x MonsterC-Teeth.STL
    • The heads have slight sockets for the teeth. Extra-Tongue.STL can be glued in optional

comments.text: What kind of paint did you use?
comments.author: Brocolee

comments.text:
I used Model Air Paint, acrylic based airbrush colors. To give some insight in how I painted them:
First a dark red layer, then some slight hue variations in different areas, mostly yellowish and bright red. On top of that a slight bright saturated green layer with a good amount of thinner. (In case of Biiiiiih bright blue.)
I also used wet cotton wool to erase paint here and there. For Biiiiih I also tried using crepe to mask ears, nose and lip which worked pretty good. Cotton wool can also be used to add slight amount of paint which helps with transitions.
comments.author: Brocolee

comments.text: Thank you, any advise to print eyes? they are really hard to get printed because of the size and shape
comments.author: Davision3d

comments.text: If you print only the 2 eyes at once print very slow or print something else with it, otherwise the layers have not enough time to cool. I always print them with a raft and support which helps with the first layers, it often still looks rough on the underside though. Looks like your eyes there came out good. If the other side looks bad you could also glue them in so they can't roll around.

author: Pieter

description.text:
Work in progress. Primi file e foto della miniCNC 3dmaker. Il lavoro non è ancora concluso e potrebbe subire cambiamenti.
www.3dmaker.systems

La miniCNC utilizza motori nema 17 e cinghie T2. L'elettronica può variare (io utilizzo la board cnc di Pibot), ma si può montare una normalissima cnc shield per arduino uno o la Ramps con il Marlin. Nella mia scheda utilizzo il firmware GRBL e come programma PC di controllo utilizzo Universal Sender g-code. I profilati di alluminio hanno le dimensioni  20 x 20 mm e 20 x 40 mm; io utilizzo quelli di OpenBuilds, ma si possono utilizzare anche di altre marche.
Spool holder for Makerbot Replicator 2/2x and guide

title: Fitting for the Xperia Z3 Compact including cover

description.text: I bought the magnetic docking station for my Xperia Z3 compact, but found out that none of the including inserts were big enough for my phone including the cover. So i made a new one. You need a pretty accurate printer since the little prongs are quite small. Also, they are not aligned 100% correct (measurements were eyeballed) so i used an exacto knife to cut them down until they snapped into the holes. I included the solidworks file in case anyone wants to edit it further
Printed in 0.2 layer height 100% infill and placing it vertically seems to give the best results

title: K40 (and others!!) Chinese Laser Air Assist Nozzle

description.text: Designed in OpenSCAD the nozzle is parametized. This is designed to printed without support, the air tube rests on the bed with the top of the nozzle connection. I use the 40 MM and it works perfectly over the top of the surface I am cutting. Due to the angle of the tubing, the air is directed towards the center of the laser hole. Note: You can lay with the wall thickness a little, but this was designed to handle 1/4 inch ID and 5/16 OD hoses. The interior tubing was made to have a back pressure to provide even distribution of the air through the tubing. If you increase the size of the tubing or the thickness of the wall, verify that the object will slice properly. Thin walls will create an air gap that is only visible after slicing. Note: No air comes from the center hole, this is the laser hole! Video of the air assist nozzle blowing through the nozzle. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cMXoxe-sKps

When making a new part, make sure to keep the sides thick enough to hold the size of the tubes that run through the nozzle. This is designed to be printed without any support of any kind. Light sanding is required as the part is printed slightly smaller then the K40 laser tip. I used a dremel to slightly grind down the interior surface

title: Huxy Pi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's not "yet another RPi case", but an all-in-one 3D printing server that features:
  • RPi 512M running weezy
  • USB WiFi dongle
  • integrated 4-port USB hub
  • power connector and switch
  • cooling fan
  • OctoPrint web host server
  • 4 USB service ports connecting up to four 3D printers or three printers and an webcam
    • The case itself has 3 parts (base, mid and top) and needs a pair of spacers, a few screws and some double-sided adhesive tape to assemble everything.
Design

You may have to customize your case before printing, depending on certain parts you use, particularly:
  • the USB hub ports positioning: you need one that have ports on adjacent sides and preferably in a 3+1 configuration (or it may interfere with the cooling fan); the huh PCB is sticked to the top case (components facing down) with double-sided adhesive tape
  • the type of power connector and switch: for, example, if you have a power connector that can be fixed with a nut, then you have to "fill" the existing holes and just provide just a round one of appropriate diameter; my switch is a push-and-hold type and is fixed on the side wall of the mid case with double-sided adhesive tape (it's strong enough!); the switch is positioned so that the button could not be accidentally released since it is leveled to the case when in "on" (pressed-and-held) position
    Should you need to customize stuff, I provided the 123dx all-in-one file (well, 123D Design is the tool I'm currently using for engineering design).
    There are also stl files of the assembled and "exploded" case to provide you with a preview of the stuff.
    • Printing

You have to print the 3 main parts (and the spacers if you want, I cut tubes from a pen!). If you have larger bed, then you may combine parts, of course.  
Assembling

The main vitamins are two M3x35 bolts that will be entered from the bottom (base) and screw directly in the top holes.
Another pair of shorter screws are used to fix a 40x40x10 cooling fan. I used initially a 12V part, then a 5V one (I thing the former will suffice and is more silent - being powered at 5V).
The last pair of small screws are used to fix the power connector, if the case. Wiring

One of the built in USB ports is used for the WiFi dongle, but the other one is internally wired to the USB hub "upstream" port (usually a mini-USB). To save space, I did this by directly soldering a pair of twisted wires to the corresponding pins of the two ports. Take care, you should never use this port to externally connect something! You should better cover it with a sticky label or a... printed cap!
You have also to wire the power, from the connector, trough the switch to the board and the fan. Isolate wire joints and solder RPi powering wires on the pads of the filtering electrolytic condenser (nearby the original micro-USP power connector).
Obviously you need an external power adapter. There is no rationale to embed it into the assemble, since you definitely do not want mains inside such a little box! Well, I'll post some more pictures somewhere and update this.

Yeap, colors are good identifiers for most people.
P-face will not run well in multiple instances. Python interpretation does consume serious processor power. And it's not about slicing (this you cannot even think about), but just using it to send gcode. It's not the comms, but the P-face GUI. Maybe Pronsole is better, but I don't like consoles.

From the deep recesses of my over-tired brain comes - Alien Jar Babies!  
These little creatures have a faces only a mother could love. The idea was to create a wierd little fetus thingy that would live in a jar of "formaldehyde". This is the 1st one in a series that we're working on.  
Ignore the bolt on his bum, he needed to be weighed down and I didn't have any lead around.  
These look sooo much cooler in person. Real gross and creepy, can't wait till we've got a row of them done.  
Thanks to Kenzo for the great model!

1) The alien is split in 2 for easy printing. Once printed, I hollowed out a bit of a cavity for some lead to weigh him down.  
2) Then I used a bit of modeling paint and aged him a bit and painted his "mouth" red.  
3) Take a baby food jar and fill with water. Add food coloring until you get that formaldehyde look (3 drops yellow, 1 drop green, 1 drop blue - I think)  
4) Insert baby into jar.  
5) Print more to keep him company

Hello There! These are some models that I had to make for a Design Tech project at school.
I made the models with a mix of 3D Scanning with an xbox Kinect and 3D Modelling in Maya. The idea of my project is that with 3d printing, you can make your own custom models and characters to use in board games, adding more customisation and putting an end to the arguments of who wants to be what piece in a game (since everyone can make their own, or better yet, themselves).
There are 3 models that I have made for this project, One is just a plain 3d scanned human on a base, just as a proof of concept. The other two show how you can add things to the models (e.g. Armour) or give the model objects to hold (e.g. Sword, Magic Staff) Any likes, downloads and/or comments are greatly appreciated as they all have to appear in my final folio!
:)
I recommend printing with supports on for the Armoured and Staff Model, but the Neutral Model should print fine without supports.

author: nms

description.text:
Quite simple and effective "one arm fan support" in two flavors :
For front or side use (see pictures)

As I noticed my proximity sensor comes with an adapter card I'm supposed to put on the ramps 2pins fan control, I realized I need to abandon the 40mm fan bracket I was using (a pair of bracket supporting the fan above the ramps). So here's a design that use only one "arm" to support a 40mm fan, for front or side use.
  • Fan is a Xilence XPF40, which is very quiet (3 pins fan connector that I mod to fit the 2pins connector on the ramps). I use the same one to cool my extruder quite effectively, and quietly.

I designed this mount so it can work with both 15mm and 20mm extrusions so virtually any Kossel variant can use it. Rather than mounting on the Z tower, this one mounts on one of the lower base cross pieces. This keeps it out of the way - a nice feature if you transport your printer to events. My Smoothie mount (posted on Thingiverse) is mounted on the back tower of my Mini Kossel and I'm always bumping it into things!

Print with 3 perimeters and 2 to 3 shells. I printed mine with 33% infill in PLA. The holes are for 3mm screws. I printed some t-nuts that work with the 6mm wide slots in 2020 that take 3mm screws. Works great.   
The ribs stiffen the frame. You will need to print or make/acquire 4 standoffs (mine are 8mm OD x 4mm tall). Attach the Duet with M3 x 10 self tapping screws with a washer under the head.  
I may tweak this design a bit after I get my Kossel 250 commissioned but this seems to work well.

comments.text: I forgot to mention, this is for the v0.6 version of Duet. I don't know if the newer v0.8.5 version is the same size and hole layout.

description.text:
Here are two endstop holders for makerbot style mechanical endstops.  
They are made to fit snuggly around a 20mm linear rails and are held tight with a single bolt.  
One is flush with the rail, designed to be activated by a plate, the other is raised up further to be activated by a wheel.  
There is a channel to accommodate the resistors and LED, so the endstop sits flush in the mount.

I attached the mounts to the rail using a M5x10mm screw and a T-nut  
The sensors are attached by 2 M3x8mm screws  
I printed with fairly high fill of 50% and a shell of 1.2mm, probably overkill adjust to your own preferences.

author: Pasquk2

description.text:
Simplicity is key to this spool holder.
This frame design has stopped my regular trouble of the filament springing off a new roll and becoming tangled around the spindle of the spool holder.
Holds filament spools up to a mximum width of 95mm (Auraurum spools)
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=74322

Using the following options: text_line_5 =
text_line_4 =
text_line_3 =
text_line_2 =
text_line_1 =
picture_shape = standard
text_reverse = no
text_size = 10
layer_height = 0.1
picture_orientation = horizontal
pane_size = large
hole_diameter = 10
text_vertical_position = 0
image_file = lithopane_new20150915-25899-1ju2y3x-0.dat
include_hole = no
number_of_layers = 14

I keep my filament spools on a rod made of 3/4" schedule 40 PVC pipe because it's cheap.  During printing, I manually turn the spool to keep slack in the filament so my extruder doesn't slip.  This device adds a bearing to the spool so it will roll freely without manual help.   
This Thing is written in OpenSCAD and is customizable.  Therefore, it will work with any spool and any rod combination as long as the rod fits inside the spool's axial hole, and for smaller rods you may need smaller bearings.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layers

Infill:

30% or more

Notes: Since this Thing is customizable, it is possible that your print will need different settings. Consider a brim if your print is very small.

You will need to attach the hubs to the spool somehow. My spools are from MonoPrice.com. They have a hollow chamber which is larger than the axial holes, so I can run rods, bands or other implements through the hub without them interfering with the filament, which is wound further out from the center of the spool. You may attach the hubs with hot-glue. It may not hold well enough but this means you could break the spools off of the hubs and reuse the hubs when the spool is depleted. Epoxy is stronger but more permanent so you would have to reuse the whole spool, moving filament from new spools onto the old ones before use. You could also use zip-ties or screw it to your spool to keep it in place. I've used screws, but zip ties could work as long as you can make them tight.. If your spools don't have a chamber at their axis, you could instead print a hub that is large enough that anchor screws can be attached closer to the perimeter of the spool so that the head is in the filament's winding area. You will have to unwind the filament to attach the screws and then wind it back onto the spool when doing it this way. Here's how I did mine: Insert the hub into the axial hole of the spool. It should be tight so it should be centered. The hub is your drilling template. Drill a mounting hole through the spool aligned with a hole in the hub flange. For #6 screws, I use a 1/8 After the first mounting hole, put a screw through the spool and the flange to prevent the hub from rotating as you drill the next two holes. If your flange is not tight, do this again with the second hole as well. Drill the second and third mounting holes and remove the hub. You now have 3 holes in the spool. You will save yourself a lot of trouble if your screws slide freely through the mounting holes. My reamer was too small, so I turned the screws partway into the hole and beat them with a hammer until they stripped. Strike the screw lightly and straight down. Pull the screw out like a common nail, but be sure to pry it straight up to avoid damage. The parts all laid out in two columns, one for each side of the spool. Parts list Each column in the picture composes a single hub for one side of the spool. I'm indicating the quantities PER SIDE (per column), so double it.
  • #6-32x1.25" screws (3)
  • #6 washers (3)
  • 3D printed hub (1)
  • 608 skate bearings (3) with 3D printed half bushings already inserted (6)
  • #6 washers (3)
  • #6 lock washers (3)
  • #6 nuts (3)
    • Place the screw through the axial hole and direct it back up through the mounting hole. Use your longest and narrowest pliers for this. Once I aligned the top of the screw with the hole, I had to push it out through the mounting hole using my thumb through the axial hole on the other side. All three screws are pushed out through the hole. Slide the hub onto the screws and into the spool axial hole. Insert the half bushings into the bearings and slide them onto the screws. Finally, a washer, a lock washer and then a nut is placed onto each screw. Tighten everything with a wrench on the nut and turn the screw from the other side with a screwdriver. Cost The bearings cost $0.50 each, the nuts and screws were $1.18, The washers were $1.18 and the lock washers were $1.18. Altogether I did both sides for about $5.25 I had washers and lock washers left over, so the next two sets only cost $3. The printed material probably costs about $0.25.

Download the bushings STL file if you need bushings and print them (you'll need 6 on each side).  Click the CUSTOMIZE button in on this page and launch the CUSTOMIZER app.  This lets you design and generate your hub by modifying the parameters to suit your project.  All units are in millimeters (mm).
The default parameters are for 3/4" PVC and 608 bearings.  Render it, and print the part twice. Depending on how you mount yours, you may need to use a printed bushing to adapt your screws to the 608 bearings if you're not using M8 screws .  I use #6 Imperial screws so I use the included 4mm ID / 8mm OD 3D printed half-bushing.  I like #6 screws because they collide on 3 fronts:  !/8" drill bit, 4mm holes, #6 screws.  It's hard to find M4 screws in the U.S. and I hate using imperial units in my designs :)  
The spool should go on one side of the hub's flange and the bearings should go on the other.  However you can rig it up to make that happen is a proper installation.  I included details about how I did mine in the post-printing section.
Do not add any tolerance to your parameters.  All aspects of this thing must fit very tightly to work properly.  Even with tight tolerances, it will still be too loose to work by just wedging it into the spool's axial hole.  You will need to affix the hubs to the spool somehow.
Once you have attached your hubs to your spool, slide the whole assembly onto your PVC rod and load your filament into your printer.

title: v2.0 pocket knife fully printable / Taschenmesser (for lefties)

description.text:
It s a pocket knife, which I draw just for fun. It s definitely no real weapon!
This version is constructed for left-handed persons. The version for right-handed persons is also available.
--> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:103155 I used a M3x15 cylinder head screw, M3 hex nut and a big M3 washer to joint the bar and the blade.
If you have the possibility you should cut the M3x15 clylinder head screw 2,9mm. Update:
There is now version 2 available. Version 2 is completely 3d printable and designed by kohlerw and me. That means you don t need any screws or nuts to manufacture it.
Only print the peg and put it in the hole through the blade. If necessary you can use a (small) drop of glue to fix the peg in the holder. Although, I printed everything in PLA, I think it s better to use ABS or maybe nylon for the holder and the peg. The knife is still in progress. Let me know your thoughts.

comments.text: No cries about it being a 'concealed weapon" on the Lefty-version...

title: Agisis Ultimate RoStock Max V2 Toolholder

description.text:
This tool holder was created because my desk was a mess of tools, tape, hotends, and glue sticks. It fits on the side of the roStock Max V2 with just two screws and holds everything you need. 4 pairs of pliers of various handle widths, 2 glue sticks holders, Digital Calipers, SeeMeCNC putty knife, Sharpie, Razor blades, Kapton Tape Holder, 4 Hot End Sizes that are labeled (.35mm, .4mm, .5mm, .7mm), Multiple slots for screw drivers  
When printing, use PLA and not ABS. I didn't put mouse ears on it for ABS so it could warp. You also need to print with Supports. I recommend 0.22mm per layer with a 35% infill. It should be strong and sturdy, not necessarily pretty.

title: Kestrel GoPro Stabilisation Gimbal Hero 1 and 3 versions

description.text: A custom brushless motor stabilisation gimbal designed to fit my 3D printed quad copter frame. The design may be a little too specific to be useable by many, it is designed for specific motors and the GoPro Hero HD (1st Gen) however I will also be putting together a variation for the GoPro 3. First test video http://youtu.be/bbDWjGNbhfU Gimbal motors are http://www.iflight-rc.com/product/iPower-Brushless-Motor-iPower-GBM-Motors-iPower-GBM2208-80T.html The gimbal controller is a martinez v3 details can be found here https://code.google.com/p/brushless-gimbal/ Instructions, parts list and OpenSCAD source to follow...

Required parts... 8 X M2x12 for motors
8 X M3x6 for motors
2 X M3x25 for connecting front and back arm
2 X M3 Nut for connecting front and back arm
2 X M3x50 for adjustable counter balance. Various M3 bearings, washers or nuts on the M3x50 to balance the gimbal.

author: nms

title: UP Box 1Kg Spool Holder 50mm Hole Revised

description.text: This is a 1Kg Spool Holder for The new UP! Box. The 1kg Filament does not fit on the holder of an UP! Box without working its way off, so I created this device to place on the original holder after placing the spool of filament. The part will keep the spool in place whilst printing. I printed the item without support on the UP! Box. The revised edition has a rounded top so it slides in easier and a thicker base so it supports the roll of filament evenly.
I printed this item without support. If you want you can use a little support for the protruding part to hold the spool on.

En ABS

This Minecraft Sword has been remixed to fit a sanded-flat Sandisk Cruzr Fit USB drive, one of the world's smallest USB drives and not very expensive. Glue the drive into the hilt and stab your computer with gigabytes of storage! The blade should friction fit as a cap on the plug end. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2Wv30270V70

It should print as-is with no supports. You may need a raft to stick the first layers.  
The fit is close so it may be tight or loose depending on your printer tolerances. If the cap fits poorly, add a small dab of super glue to one interior face. Let it dry; that should thicken it enough. Don't add too much. Or sand/shave the inside if necessary.
